abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>When evaluating a newly developed statistical test, an important step is to check its type 1 error (T1E) control using simulations. This is often achieved by the standard simulation design S0 under the so‐called “theoretical” null of no association. In practice, the whole‐genome association analyses scan through a large number of genetic markers (<jats:inline-graphic xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xlink:href="graphic/gepi22172-math-0001.png" xlink:title="urn:x-wiley:07410395:media:gepi22172:gepi22172-math-0001" />s) for the ones associated with an outcome of interest (<jats:inline-graphic xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xlink:href="graphic/gepi22172-math-0002.png" xlink:title="urn:x-wiley:07410395:media:gepi22172:gepi22172-math-0002" />), where <jats:inline-graphic xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xlink:href="graphic/gepi22172-math-0003.png" xlink:title="urn:x-wiley:07410395:media:gepi22172:gepi22172-math-0003" /> comes from an alternative while the majority of <jats:inline-graphic xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xlink:href="graphic/gepi22172-math-0004.png" xlink:title="urn:x-wiley:07410395:media:gepi22172:gepi22172-math-0004" />s are not associated with <jats:inline-graphic xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xlink:href="graphic/gepi22172-math-0005.png" xlink:title="urn:x-wiley:07410395:media:gepi22172:gepi22172-math-0005" />; the <jats:inline-graphic xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xlink:href="graphic/gepi22172-math-0006.png" xlink:title="urn:x-wiley:07410395:media:gepi22172:gepi22172-math-0006" /> relationships are under the “empirical” null. This reality can be better represented by two other simulation designs, where design S1.1 simulates <jats:inline-graphic xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xlink:href="graphic/gepi22172-math-0007.png" xlink:title="urn:x-wiley:07410395:media:gepi22172:gepi22172-math-0007" /> from an<jats:italic>alternative</jats:italic> model based on <jats:inline-graphic xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xlink:href="graphic/gepi22172-math-0008.png" xlink:title="urn:x-wiley:07410395:media:gepi22172:gepi22172-math-0008" />, then evaluates its association with independently generated <jats:inline-graphic xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xlink:href="graphic/gepi22172-math-0009.png" xlink:title="urn:x-wiley:07410395:media:gepi22172:gepi22172-math-0009" />; while design S1.2 evaluates the association between permutated <jats:inline-graphic xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xlink:href="graphic/gepi22172-math-0010.png" xlink:title="urn:x-wiley:07410395:media:gepi22172:gepi22172-math-0010" /> and <jats:inline-graphic xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xlink:href="graphic/gepi22172-math-0011.png" xlink:title="urn:x-wiley:07410395:media:gepi22172:gepi22172-math-0011" />. More than a decade ago, Efron (2004) has noted the important distinction between the “theoretical” and “empirical” null in false discovery rate control. Using scale tests for variance heterogeneity, direct univariate, and multivariate interaction tests as examples, here we show that not all null simulation designs are equal. In examining the accuracy of a likelihood ratio test, while simulation design S0 suggested the method being accurate, designs S1.1 and S1.2 revealed its increased empirical T1E rate if applied in real data setting. The inflation becomes more severe at the tail and does not diminish as sample size increases. This is an important observation that calls for new practices for methods evaluation and T1E control interpretation.</jats:p>
